Møller.jpg | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1837|4|21}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|1922|1|22|1837|4|21}} | death_place = | occupation = writer, politician, teacher | nationality = Danish | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = 1908 [[Nobel Peace Prize]] | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }} <!-- Unsourced image removed: [[File:bajer.jpg|thumb|right|Fredrik Bajer {{Deletable image-caption|date=May 2012}}]] --> '''Fredrik Bajer''' (April 21, 1837 – January 22, 1922) was a [[Denmark|Danish]] writer, teacher, and [[pacifism|pacifist]] [[politician]] who received the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] in 1908. The son of a clergyman, Bajer served as an officer in the Danish army, fighting in the 1864 war against [[Prussia]] and [[Austria]] where he was promoted to the rank of first lieutenant. He was discharged in 1865, and moved to Copenhagen where he became a teacher, translator and writer. He entered the [[Rigsdag|Danish Parliament]] in 1872 as a member of [[Parliament of Denmark|Folketinget]] and held a seat there for the following 23 years. As a member of parliament, he worked for the use of international arbitration to solve conflicts among nations, and it is due to Bajer's efforts that foreign relations became part of the work of the Danish Parliament and that Denmark participated in the [[Inter-Parliamentary Union]] from the beginning and earned a distinguished position among its members.<ref>Skou, Kaare R. (2005). ''Dansk politik A-Å'' {{da icon}}. Aschehoug, p. 109. ISBN 87-11-11652-8.</ref><ref>Andersen, Holger (1953). "Den danske rigsdag og det interparlamentariske arbejde" {{da icon}} in Fabricius, Knud; Bomholt, Jul.; Hjelholt, Holger; Mackeprang, M.; Møller, Andr. (eds.): ''Den danske rigsdag 1849–1949 bind VI''. Copenhagen: J. H. Schultz Forlag, pp. 415–416.</ref> He supported many peace organizations, both inside Denmark and Europe-wide, and helped guide the passage of a bill to reach arbitration agreements with [[Sweden]] and [[Norway]]. ==Quotation== <blockquote>"Always we must bear in mind that law has to be substituted for power, that care must be taken to serve the interests of law."<ref>[http://www.brainyquote.com/quotes/authors/f/fredrik_bajer.html Fredrik Bajer Quotations]</ref></blockquote> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.nobel.se/peace/laureates/1908/index.html Nobel Committee information on 1908 laureates] {{Nobel Peace Prize Laureates 1901-1925}} {{Authority control|VIAF=107637271}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Bajer, Fredrik | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = April 21, 1837 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = January 22, 1922 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bajer, Fredrik}} [[Category:1837 births]] [[Category:1922 deaths]] [[Category:Danish writers]] [[Category:Danish Nobel laureates]] [[Category:Nobel Peace Prize laureates]] [[Category:Inter-Parliamentary Union]] [[Category:Members of the Folketing]] {{Denmark-politician-stub}} {{Denmark-writer-stub}}
